trial_identification.studytitle: Formation and Severity of Pressure Ulcers Associated With 4% Albumin vs. 0.9% Sodium Chloride
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The Formation and Severity of Pressure Ulcers Associated With 4% Albumin vs. 0.9% Sodium Chloride Administration (Substudy of SAFE Protocol 153711)

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Other diseases of the mouth, teeth, oesophagus, digestive system including liver and colon

interventions.interventions:
Treatment: drugs - 4% Albumin / 0.9% Sodium Chloride
Treatment: drugs: 4% Albumin / 0.9% Sodium Chloride

primaryOutcome.outcome: Patients receiving 4% Albumin will have less incidence and reduced severity of pressure injuries.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Is there a difference in the incidence of pressure injuries between those patients resuscitated with 4% Albumin and patients resuscitated with 0.9% Sodium Chloride
Is there a difference in the severity of pressure injuries between those patients resuscitated with 4% Albumin and patients resuscitated with 0.9% Sodium Chloride.

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: In addition to the SAFE exclusion criteria, pre-existing pressure ulcers (developed prior to ICU admission) will also be excluded-

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Patients resuscitated with 4% Albumin will have less incidence and reduced severity of pressure injuries than patients resuscitated with 0.9% Sodium Chloride due to the improved intravascular oncotic pressure effected from higher albumin levels.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Anthony D, Reynolds T, Russell L. An investigation into the use of serum albumin in pressure sore prediction. J Adv Nurs. 2000 Aug;32(2):359-65. Hanan K, Scheele L. Albumin vs. weight as a predictor of nutritional status and pressure ulcer development. Ostomy Wound Manage. 1991 Mar-Apr;33:22-7. Cullum N, Clark M. Intrinsic factors associated with pressure sores in elderly people. J Adv Nurs. 1992 Apr;17(4):427-31. Goodrich C, March K. From ED to ICU: a focus on prevention of skin breakdown. Crit Care Nurs Q. 1992 May;15(1):1-13. Peerless JR, Davies A, Klein D, Yu D. Skin complications in the intensive care unit. Clin Chest Med. 1999 Jun;20(2):453-67, x. Review. Matthewson M. Colloids vs. crystalloids. Critical Care Nurse. Vol 11 (5), 1985

contact.name: Shena M Graham, BN
